1. Licensing requirements: Adoption agencies must be licensed by the appropriate state agency before they can operate. They must meet specific standards for safety, health, and overall well-being of children placed through the agency.

2. Accreditation: Adoption agencies must be accredited by national or international organizations in order to provide adoption services. Accreditation ensures that the agency meets certain ethical and professional standards.

3. Background checks: Adoption agencies must conduct extensive background checks on all staff and volunteers who will have contact with children, as well as anyone seeking to adopt.

4. Training: Adoption agencies must provide comprehensive training for adoptive families, including education about the legal and emotional aspects of adoption, as well as preparation for parenting an adopted child.

5. Adoption policies and procedures: Adoption agencies must have clear policies and guidelines for all aspects of their adoption programs, including selection criteria for adoptive families, matching families with children, and post-adoption support.

6. Financial transparency: Adoption agencies must provide clear information about their fees and expenses, and comply with all legal requirements related to financial disclosure and billing.

7. Record-keeping: Adoption agencies must maintain accurate and complete records of all adoption-related activities, including correspondence, financial transactions, and placement information.

These are just a few of the legal requirements that adoption agencies must meet to operate legally and ethically. Additionally, adoption laws vary by state and country, so agencies must also comply with specific legal requirements in the jurisdictions where they operate.
